title: Unusually Large Extent of Pagetic Vertebral Ankylosis in a Patient with Ankylosing Spondylitis
patient: A 76-year-old male was referred to our radiology department to perform an abdominal computed tomography (CT) as part of the follow-up after Whipple surgery for pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm. He had a prior history of Paget’s disease (PD) and ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and was totally asymptomatic.\nCT showed characteristic features of AS (syndesmophytes, vertebral squaring, fused costovertebral joints, and fused sacro-iliac joints) associated with typical bone remodeling features of PD (coarsening of the primary trabeculae, marginal vertebral sclerosis) resulting in an extensive pagetic vertebral ankylosis (PVA) with involvement of the dorsolumbar spine, sacrum (), iliac bones (), and costovertebral joints (not shown). MRI demonstrated a normal fatty bone marrow signal consistent with uncomplicated PD in the late or inactive state (not shown).
